headline: Nothing Can Dim Rider's Golden Glow
summary: McLain Ward hopped off the jet from humid Hong Kong, where he helped the United States Equestrian Team secure an Olympic gold medal, his second career team gold, and hopped onto Phillipa, the statuesque chestnut mare he rode to an unremarkable 33rd-place finish in a $7,500 Open Jumper event Tuesday afternoon under summer postcard conditions at the Hampton Classic. He did not appear perturbed by the disparity: the gold medal Olympian finishes in the middle of the pack in a small potatoes class back home in New York, where he operates Castle Hill Farm in Brewster, in Putnam County, with his father, Barney.

summary: WALLACE--John F. Jr., of West Hempstead on October 8, 2007. Beloved husband of Loretto T. (nee Rigney); devoted father of John F. III, Stephen J. (Jeanne), Robert S. (Maureen); cherished grandfather of Martha, Sara, Jake, Peter, Meaghan, Joseph, Mary Kate, Bobby and Erin. Reposing BarnesSorrentino Funeral Home Inc., 539 Hempstead Ave., West Hempstead (1 mile North Exit 17N SS Parkway) on Thursday and Friday, 2-4 and 7-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial, St. Thomas The Apostle R.C. Church, West Hempstead on Saturday at 10:30am. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to John F. Wallace Jr. Scholarship Fund, care of Fordham University, 888 7th Ave., NY, NY 10019, attention: Keith Norton.

headline: You Should Be in Pictures
summary: You don't have to be a megacollector to commission a portrait, but it helps. ''I wouldn't do one unless the person really interests me,'' says Marilyn Minter, who recently painted Stephanie Seymour. Other prominent artists, like Francesco Clemente, also pick and choose their subjects. For the rest of us, there's the Manhattan-based company Portraits Inc., which has 130 artists poised to immortalize you (or your pet) in any medium. So what is the price of vanity? Francesco Clemente

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths LODERHOSE, RICHARD E
summary: LODERHOSE--Richard E. Born in Brooklyn, New York, August 16, 1925, he passed peacefully on April 10, 2008, in Tampa, Florida. He attended Richmond Hill High School and the University of Rochester as a Naval cadet. He served in the U.S. Navy during World War Two as a Specialist for Welfare and Recreation and was the organist for all chapel activities at the U.S. Naval Base in Little Creek, Maryland. Subsequent to his naval service he was employed in the family business in New York City, then known as the United Paste and Glue Company. Along with his father, Herman C. Loderhose, he built United into the national adhesive manufacturer called United Resin Products, Inc. He was a gifted CEO, master salesman, and innovator in packaging patents, coatings and adhesives. In 1997, Mr. Loderhose sold United to the Henkel Corporation and remained with Henkel for the next four years as a senior director of the company. Mr. Loderhose had a lifelong passion for music, particularly the theatre organ. He was well known for his preservation, restoration, perfor mance, and support of the instrument. The gem of his extensive collection being the 55 rank New York Paramount Studio Theatre Organ, until recently located at the family owned Bay Theatre in Seal Beach, California. In June, 2007, Mr. Loderhose gifted this magnificent instrument to The Beatitudes Campus in Phoenix, Arizona where it is being reinstalled for the enjoyment of the residents, members, congregants, staff and the entire Phoenix and theatre organ community. He was a past president and founding member of the American Theatre Organ Society. He played the organ professionally under the name Dick Scott and made numerous recordings for his own label, Renwick Recordings, Inc. as well as for United Artists Records. An avid yachtsman, Mr. Loderhose also had a great passion for World War Two Air Sea Rescue boats. He refurbished and restored numerous rescue/crash boats during his lifetime (Music Man I through VI) and was often a speaker at events sponsored by crash boat organizations throughout the country. His philanthropy included the donation of a restored 64 foot rescue boat to the Sea Scouts of Marina Del Rey, California. When Mr. Loderhose retired from the glue business in 1997 he spent most of his remaining years in Newport Beach, California attending to his yachting and musical interests. He was a member of the Balboa Bay Club, Newport Beach, California. His final years were spent in Tampa, Florida. He is at rest now knowing that whatever his passion, he succeeded. He would want everyone to know that he truly had a ball and would go out playing ''Ain't Misbehavin'' or ''Anchors Away'' if he could; and those who knew him would agree. Life was good. He dearly loved his family and friends and was grateful for the life he led. He is survived by his daughters, Rena L. Singer and her husband Joel B. Singer, Mari J. Galloway and her husband, Michael G. Galloway; six grandchildren, Beryl, Garrett and Lindsay Firestone and Robin, Adam and Shannon Galloway, his loving sister, Grace E. Kerr, and former wife, Marie Tepper. Remembered lovingly by his first wife, and lifelong friend, the late Jane D. Loderhose. Donations can be made to the American Theatre Organ Society, or the charity of your choice in his memory. Memorial service to take place at Prince of Peace Lutheran Church in Phoenix, Arizona on Saturday, April 19, 2008 at 2pm. Marsicano-B. Marion Reed-Stowers Funeral Home.

The Cancer Research and Treatment Fund, Inc., mourns the passing of its distinguished past President and longtime member of its Executive Committee and Board of Directors. His wisdom, advice and commitment was matched by his eloquence, spirit and generosity. We extend our sympathy to his wife Helen and his family. Richard Rose, President Richard T. Silver, M.D., Medical Director

headline: Letters
summary: A Case of the Blues Benjamin Wallace-Wells's erudite analysis of ''the end of Republican America'' did not get to the core of its ascendancy in the first place (March 30). Discounting the gains from persuading lunch-bucket types to vote red, using social-issue wedges, elephant nation took to its heart the maxim of the joke: What's the difference between Democrats and Republicans? Democrats are tax and spend; Republicans are borrow and spend. And borrow and spend is much more politically correct.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths BOUDREAUX, JONATHAN JUDE
summary: BOUDREAUX--Jonathan Jude, died at the Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan on August 11, 2008, after a three-and-a-half year war with acute myelogenous leukemia. He was 36. Jonathan was born and raised in Thibodaux, Louisiana. He attended Nicholls State University in Thibodaux, and received a Master's degree in Theatre from Louisiana Tech University in Ruston, Louisiana. He moved to New York City in the autumn of 1996. He joined the Box Office staff at The New Victory Theater in the early days of the ''new'' 42nd Street when shuttered porn shops still lined the street. He then served a brief tenure at the William Morris Agency before becoming Executive Assistant to the President of The Rolfe Company, a Manhattan-based agency representing theatrical designers. A walking encyclopedia of American popular culture, Jonathan founded and served as Editor-in-Chief and Managing Director of www.tvdvdreviews.com, one of the first Web sites dedicated to reviewing television productions released on DVD. The site, which earned a loyal following for its pithy and timely reviews, regularly receives upwards of 3,000 visitors a day. From the time of his diagnosis in February 2005 until his death, Jonathan met his cancer with characteristically fierce stubbornness, irreverent humor, black sarcasm, and an even-keeled, clear head. His tenacity-combined with the unyielding support of friends and family--enabled him to survive countless rounds of chemotherapy, two bone marrow transplants, two brain tumors, and a cord blood transplant. He left his family and friends after affirming on multiple occasions that be couldn't have been happier and more, content with the life he led and the adventures he shared. Jonathan Boudreaux is survived by his longtime partner and companion, Christopher W. Czajka; his parents, Gail C. and Ronnie Boudreaux of Thibodaux; his sister Jenise and brother-inlaw Brian Jennings, also of Thibodaux; his grandparents, Orena and ''Red'' Adams; and countless aunts, uncles, cousins, neighbors, and family friends in Louisiana. He is also survived by scores of friends in New York City and across the country. Particularly steadfast in their support of Jonathan throughout his disease have been his boss and good friend Mickey Rolfe, Nicole Roberts, Kelly Demaret, Marsha Drummond, Kerri Chyka, and Sam Buffer, all of New York; Duane and Barb Czajka and Billie Lape of Rochester, NY; Kay and Eamon Daly and Katie Heilman of Chicago, IL; Allison Dillon of Nashville, TN; Caroline and Colette LaGarde of Raceland, LA; and the staff of the Education Department at Thirteen/WNET. Jonathan will also be remembered and celebrated by a new generation of relatives and friends, including his nephew Draven Michael Jennings and young Norah Elizabeth Czajka and Ian Stuart Lape. At Jonathan's request, no memorial service or funeral will be held. His most ardent wish was for his family and friends to briefly mourn his passing, and then live their lives to their happiest and fullest potential. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the National Marrow Donor Program (www.marrow.org), which provides patients around the world with life-saving bone marrow, cord blood, and stem cell transplants. He will be sorely missed. BOUDREAUX--Jonathan J. Our clients join me in grieving Jonathan's death and in sending our deep respect and condolences to his partner, Chris; his parents Gail and Ronnie; and his sister, Jenise. Jonathan's three-and-a-half year battle with leukemia was a lesson in grace, dignity, and the complete absence of selfpity --one we'd give anything not to have had to learn this way. We are profoundly indebted to him for his diligence and wisdom. We'll remember him for his gallantry, his unfailing sense of humor, that smile, and his sheer cussedness. So much more than a colleague for nine years, he was like the kid brother I never had. Mickey Rolfe The Rolfe Company, Inc.

headline: BITS
summary: San Francisco in a Wi-Fi Fog It has been more than two years since Mayor Gavin Newsom of San Francisco championed the idea of blanketing the city with free wireless Internet access. After fits and starts and protracted negotiations, the plan appears to have fizzled for now, derailed by a mix of city politics and business challenges.

headline: The Huckabee Factor
summary: Mike Huckabee walked into the lobby of the Des Moines Marriott at 5:30 a.m. on Dec. 3, deposited an armful of dirty laundry at the desk and checked to make sure he was being credited with Marriott Rewards points toward his next stay. Then, accompanied by his wife, Janet, his daughter, Sarah, and his press secretary, Alice Stewart -- who doubles as his Boston Marathon trainer -- he walked into the dark, freezing morning, climbed into a waiting S.U.V. and headed for Central College in Pella, Iowa. Huckabee, a former Arkansas governor, was in a buoyant mood on three hours of sleep. The night before, his commercial flight suffered a long Chicago holdover on the way from Boston, but he had reason to hope that his days at the mercy of the airlines might be numbered. A Des Moines Register opinion poll had just shown Huckabee passing Mitt Romney to take the lead in the run-up to the Jan. 3 caucus. His picture, he already knew, was on the front page of that morning's USA Today. Now he was headed to Central College, to appear, surrounded by enthusiastic students, on ''The Early Show'' on CBS. This kind of momentum, he hoped, would finally produce enough cash to allow him to charter his own plane. The governor was especially happy that morning about an impending endorsement he expected (and received the following day) from Tim LaHaye, the author of the apocalyptic ''Left Behind'' series of novels. ''Left Behind'' is wildly popular among evangelicals, who have bought more than 65 million copies, making LaHaye a very rich man and one of the few writers who is also a major philanthropist. Recently he donated a hockey rink to Jerry Falwell's Liberty University, although some members of the faculty there deride ''Left Behind'' as science fiction. Huckabee, an ordained Southern Baptist minister, has no such reservations. He considers the ''Left Behind'' books, in which the world comes to a violent end as Jesus triumphs over Satan, a ''compelling story written for nontheologians.''

headline: Testing Religion's Waters
summary: A fund-raiser was held Tuesday night in Washington for a nascent political action committee that is hoping to reach out to evangelicals and other Christians on behalf of Senator Barack Obama. The committee, the Matthew 25 Network, is being organized by Mara Vanderslice, who was director of religious outreach for Senator John Kerry's Democratic presidential campaign in 2004 and has done similar work for, among others, Gov. Ted Strickland of Ohio and Senator Bob Casey of Pennsylvania, both Democrats.

headline: Bertelsmann Picks a Publishing Industry Outsider to Head Random House
summary: On the day that Bertelsmann, the German media conglomerate, quelled weeks of speculation by announcing that Markus Dohle, head of the company's printing unit, would take over as chief executive of Random House, industry executives were largely reserving judgment on what it would mean to have a relative outsider in charge of the world's largest publisher of consumer books. Mr. Dohle, 39, will succeed Peter W. Olson, Random House's current chief executive, on June 1. Mr. Olson, 58, who led the publishing division for the last decade, is in negotiations for a senior faculty position at Harvard Business School, according to a person knowledgeable about his plans. Mr. Olson declined to comment.

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
summary: FUNDING A CENSOR? Hedge funds are financing some of China's elaborate security systems, including the nation's extreme control over the Internet. Now, the growing ties between China's surveillance sector and American capital markets are starting to draw Washington's attention. GUILTY PLEA IN TAX CASE David Amir Makov pleaded guilty in a federal case involving promoters of questionable tax shelters, a move that is expected to help the government's case against the four remaining defendants. [C1.]

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths LINDSAY, NANCY DALLEY
summary: LINDSAY--Nancy Dalley, on June 7th after a long and courageous battle with a pituitary tumor. Beloved wife for 58 years of Robert V. Lindsay, mother of Cameron Lindsay of Denver, Colorado, Tinker Lindsay of Hollywood, California and Robert D. and daughter-in-law Teresa Lindsay of Locust Valley, New York. Grandmother of Thomas and Dorothy Beatty, Jonathan and Andrew Warkentin, and Robert T., James, Alexander and Duncan Lindsay. Mrs. Lindsay was born in New York City and attended the Lenox School, Greenwood School and Vassar College. A noted breeder and judge of dogs, she filled judging assignments on three continents, including judge of Best in Show at the Westminster Kennel Club show. Mrs. Lindsay was a founding trustee of the American Kennel Club Museum of the Dog in Saint Louis, Missouri. She also is a past trustee of the Geraldine Rockefeller Dodge Foundation and served on the boards of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, the Cooper Union, the Animal Medical Center, the ASPCA, the Westminster Kennel Foundation, the East Woods School and the Dutchess Day School. She served as chairman of the Women's Committee of the American Museum of Natural History, and in 1976 as Vice-Chairman in London of the U.S. Bicentennial Committee which brought together collections of American Indian art and artifacts from world-wide sources for a London exposition in honor of the Bicentennial. A memorial service will be held Friday, June 13 at 11am, at St. Peter's Church on Deep Hollow Road in Millbrook NY. (Lithgow). In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to Hospice, Inc. Dutchess County, 374 Violet Avenue, Poughkeepsie NY, 12601.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths EDWARDS, JUNIUS
summary: EDWARDS--Junius, 78, died peacefully at home in New York City on March 22, 2008. He is survived by his beloved wife of 50 years, Inger Marie, his two sons, Eric and Tony, his daughter Ellen, four grandchildren, and one greatgrandchild. Born in 1929 in Alexandria, Louisiana, Junius Edwards joined the Army at 18, served for nine years in Korea and Japan, and worked in the Judge Advocate General Corps and the Army Counter Intelligence Corps. After his honorable discharge he went to study at the University of Oslo, Norway using his GI Bill, where he continued to pursue his passion for writing. In 1958 he won first prize in the Writer's Digest Short Story Contest for ''Liars Don't Qualify'' and in 1959, he received a Eugene F. Saxton Fellowship for creative writing. His published work also includes short stories ''Duel with the Clock,'' ''Mother Dear and Daddy,'' and the novel ''If We Must Die''. His writing primarily focused on racial and personal problems faced by the African-American soldier and African-Americans living in the South. During the 1960s in New York, Junius Edwards worked as a copywriter for various advertising agencies such as Ogilvy & Mather, Ted Bates Inc., and Norman, Craig, & Kummel. He went on to establish Junius Edwards Inc., one of the first blackowned advertising agencies in New York City with clients that included Carver Federal Savings Bank, Faberge, Liggett & Myers, and The Greater New York Savings Bank. He later worked as a consultant and Special Fellow for United Nations Unitar, while also expanding into several entrepreneurial endeavors in the health, travel, publishing, and airline industries. We, your adoring family, thank you for being a wonderful and inspiring man, a great father, and loving husband.We love you Papa. Messages of condolence can be sent to JJEdwards@aol.com

Lindsay, mother of Cameron Lindsay of Denver, Colorado, Tinker Lindsay of Hollywood, California and Robert D. and daughter-in-law Teresa Lindsay of Locust Valley, New York. Grandmother of Thomas and Dorothy Beatty, Jonathan and Andrew Warkentin, and Robert T., James, Alexander and Duncan Lindsay. Mrs. Lindsay was born in New York City and attended the Lenox School, Greenwood School and Vassar College. A noted breeder and judge of dogs, she filled judging assignments on three continents, including judge of Best in Show at the Westminster Kennel Club show. Mrs. Lindsay was a founding trustee of the American Kennel Club Museum of the Dog in Saint Louis, Missouri. She also is a past trustee of the Geraldine Rockefeller Dodge Foundation and served on the boards of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, the Cooper Union, the Animal Medical Center, the ASPCA, the Westminster Kennel Foundation, the East Woods School and the Dutchess Day School. She served as chairman of the Women's Committee of the American Museum of Natural History, and in 1976 as Vice-Chairman in London of the U.S. Bicentennial Committee which brought together collections of American Indian art and artifacts from world-wide sources for a London exposition in honor of the Bicentennial. A memorial service will be held Friday, June 13 at 11am, at St. Peter's Church on Deep Hollow Road in Millbrook NY. (Lithgow). In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to Hospice, Inc. Dutchess County, 374 Violet Avenue, Poughkeepsie NY, 12601.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths GOLDEN, WILLIAM T
summary: GOLDEN--William T. The Board of Directors and Scientific Advisory Counsel of Alliance for Cancer Gene Therapy, Inc. (ACGT) mourn the passing of William T. Golden, who provided early insight and support for ACGT's mission to find a cure for cancer through gene therapy research. Bill Golden's vision within the scientific and philanthropic community was an inspiration to us all. Edward & Barbara Netter, Co-Founders GOLDEN--William T. The members of the Department of Biological Sciences at Columbia University mourn the death of their illustrious alumnus, Bill Golden. Both through his support of Departmental efforts and his personal friendships, Bill enriched our science and our lives. We send our deepest sympathy to his daughters Dr. Pamela Golden and Sybil Golden, Chairman of the Black Rock Forest Consortium, to his wife, Catherine Morrison, and to all his family and friends who miss him as we do. GOLDEN--William T. The Trustees of the Neurosciences Research Foundation and the scientists and staff of The Neurosciences Institute in La Jolla are deeply saddened by the passing of William T. Golden, our esteemed colleague and dear friend. Beginning in 1981, Bill served the Foundation with great dedication as trustee, chairman, and chairman emeritus. We shall miss his wise counsel, keen intellect, and unsurpassed commitment to science for the benefit of the public. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his family and to all he touched over his remarkable lifetime. William D. Walsh, Chairman Gerald M. Edelman, President W. Einar Gall, Research Director GOLDEN--William T. The New York Academy of Medicine acknowledges with profound sorrow the death of William T. Golden. We join many in remembering his keen intellect and contributions to science, and we are especially grateful for his friendship, extraordinary contribution of wisdom and generosity to the Academy. The Academy Board, Fellows and staff extend deepest condolences to his family. Jo Ivey Boufford, M.D., President Thomas Q. Morris, M.D., Chairman, Board of Trustees GOLDEN--William T. It is with deepest sympathy that the Board of Directors and Staff of The Catskill Center for Conservation and Development express our condolences to the family of Bill Golden, who served on our board for over 26 years. We will remember him with much admiration and affection for his profound wisdom and sense of humor. He will be greatly missed. His daughter, Sibyl R. Golden continues to serve on our board. H. Claude Shostal, President, Tom Alworth, Executive Director

Petrucelli and his wife Margaret, Nancy and her husband Michael Pellicione and Steven T. Petrucelli. Cherished grandfather of Michael, Daniel, Emma and Keira. Dear brother of Joseph, Louise Montagano, Beatrice Callagy, and the late Richard. Brother-in-law of Carol Guedez. Retired NYC Fire Department Lieutenant. The family will receive friends at the Westchester Funeral Home, Inc., Eastchester, Tuesday and Wednesday 2-4 and 79pm. A service will be held at the funeral home on Thursday, March 6 at 12 noon. Entombment to follow at Ferncliff Mausoleum.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths GOLDEN, WILLIAM T
summary: GOLDEN--William T . The Directors, Officers and Staff of General American Investors Company, Inc. are deeply saddened by the passing of our esteemed colleague, Bill Golden. A Director for 35 years and a Director Emeritus since 1996, Bill served the Company with great distinction and dedication, providing us with the benefit of his keen intellect, broad knowledge and wise counsel. We extend our condolences to the members of his family. Spencer Davidson, Chairman of the Board, President and Chief Executive Officer, General American Investors Company, Inc. GOLDEN--William T., on October 7th, just short of his 98th birthday. Adored Husband of Catherine Morrison Golden and of the late Sibyl Levy Golden. Beloved Father of Sibyl R. Golden and Pamela P. Golden. Loving Son of the late S. Herbert and Rebecca H. Golden. Devoted Brother of the late Barry Golden. Dear friend to many. Funeral private. Memorial Service at a later date. GOLDEN--William T. It is with profound sadness and deep affection that the Trustees and Staff of the American Museum of Natural History mourn the death of William T. Golden, our superb Chairman from 1989 to 1994, distinguished Chairman Emeritus thereafter, and an esteemed Trustee for nearly 40 years. Bill was one of the Museum's guiding stars whose wise counsel, incisive intelligence, passionate involvement, and commitment to science were unsurpassed. In his distinguished and highly influential career, Bill dedicated himself tirelessly to increasing the understanding of science among both the public and policymakers, championing public support of the scientific endeavor as an investment in our country's future, and fostering a scientifically literate citizenry. The Museum was enormously privileged to have his outstanding leadership and able hand during a time of important institutional growth and transformation. His leadership and longstanding generosity are captured in his role in helping the Museum advance the frontiers of science, including building vanguard research programs in such areas as microbial biology, and, perhaps most tangibly, in the beautiful Golden Corridor of Science, which extends through the Museum's research areas and bridges scientists and disciplines. It stands as a symbol of Bill's devotion to the scientific pursuit as a catalyst for the advancement of society and humanity, which was a hallmark of his remarkable life. He found unending joy and fascination in science and in the wonders of nature. In this and so many other ways, he will always be a touchstone for all of us at the Museum. He was a renaissance man, a great New Yorker, a great American, and a great citizen of the world. Most of all, Bill was the dearest of friends, forever young in spirit and intellect and we shall miss him terribly. Our deepest condolences go to his beloved wife Catherine, his daughter Sibyl, Chairman of the Museum's Center for Biodiversity and Conservation, his daughter Pamela, and the many whose lives he touched. Lewis W. Bernard, Chairman Ellen V. Futter, President GOLDEN--William T. The entire Barnard College community is deeply saddened by the death of our long-serving trustee William T. Golden. Bill was a generous, active, and steadfast supporter of Barnard for over 30 years. For his many contributions to the College, as well as his lifelong dedication to advancing public support for the sciences and the humanities, he was presented with the Barnard Medal of Distinction in 1999. Sincere condolences are offered to his wife Catherine, daughters Sibyl and Pamela, and his entire family. Anna Quindlen, Chair of the Board Judith Shapiro, President GOLDEN--William T. The Trustees, Faculty, and Staff of The Mount Sinai Medical Center mourn the passing of William T. Golden, a dedicated member of our Boards of Trustees were he served with distinction for more than 52 years. Bill Golden's personal commitment to science at Mount Sinai was outstanding. In addition to being one of the founders of The Mount Sinai School of Medicine, he generously supported research endowment programs and other trustee initiative. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Catherine, his daughters, Dr. Pamela P. Golden and Sibyl R. Golden, and the entire family. Peter W. May, Chairman The Board of Trustees, Kenneth L. Davis, M.D., President and CEO, The Mount Sinai Medical Center GOLDEN--William T. The Board of Trustees and staff of The New York Hall of Science mourns the passing of William T. Golden. His vision and leadership launched the position of Science Advisor to the President during the Truman administration. His lifelong commitment to education in the sciences and substantive international and domestic science policy discussions have enriched the nation and will benefit generations to come. Nicholas Donofrio, Co-Chair Ivan Seidenberg, Co-Chair Marilyn Hoyt, Pres & CEO Alan Friedman, Consulting Senior Scientist

headline: Colorful and Well Connected, a Laptop That Stands Out
summary: It's summer, so why shouldn't one's laptop match one's hot-pink bikini? Dell's Studio line comes in seven colors and offers some impressive computing power inside. The laptops, which start at $799, use Intel Core 2 Duo processors and have up to 320 gigabytes of hard drive space. Optional Blu-ray or DVD recording drives ensure you can watch a movie under your beach umbrella, while built-in Wi-Fi, cellular broadband and Bluetooth keep things connected.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths Livezey, Lowell W.
summary: LIVEZEY--Lowell W. New York Theological Seminary announces with great sadness the passing on December 9, 2007, of Dr. Lowell W. Livezey, Professor of Urban and Religious Studies and Director of the Ecologies of Learning Project at the Seminary. Dr. Livezey directed large studies of urban congregations, using ethnographic data assembled in collaboration with colleagues and students in Chicago, Boston, and New York. He argued that the "religion factor" is more salient than often recognized in the economic, demographic, and spatial restructuring of modern industrial cities. Dr. Livezey received the B.A. from Swarthmore College and the M. Th. and D. Min. degrees from the University of Chicago School of Divinity. He spent two decades in the peace movement before beginning his second career in studying communities, meanings, culture, and social change. In 2005, Dr. Livezey became the founding Director of the Ecologies of Learning Project (EOL) at NYTS, funded through a major grant from Lilly Endowment Inc. Lowell Livezey was a person of immense insight, wisdom and compassion, of great integrity and depth, and an outstanding colleague. He embodied the values of teaching, learning and research that lie at the heart of the scholarly endeavor. He also was a friend, a caring human being, someone around whom community was easily formed. In the language that is familiar to the people of faith, Lowell simply was a blessing to NYTS. Lowell helped us all understand the life and work of the churches and especially the intellectual task of preparation for ministry more clearly. Dr. Craig Dykstra, Senior Vice President, Religion of Lilly Endowment Inc., stated that "Lowell Livezey's work on religion and urban culture is path-breaking -a permanent contribution. His patient, generous and imaginative work with pastors and other religious leaders in Chicago, Boston and New York, as well as with scholars, will bear great fruit for many years to come." Dr. Livezey is survived by his wife, Dr. Lois Gehr Livezey, Director of the Globalization Project of the Center for World Christianity at NYTS. Contributions in Dr. Livezey's memory may be made to the Lowell W. Livezey Fund, Ecologies of Learning, New York Theological Seminary, 475 Riverside Drive, Suite 500, New York, NY 10115. A memorial will be held on January 26, 2008, 10:00 am, at The Riverside Church, 490 Riverside Drive, New York City. Dr. Dale T. Irvin, President Dr. Diane T. Ashley, Chair of the Board of Trustees

headline: BITS
summary: If Apple Met Blu-ray Rumors are flying fast and furious over what Steven P. Jobs, above, will pull out of his blue-jean pocket next week at the Macworld Expo in San Francisco. These include a movie rental service for iTunes, a supersmall notebook computer, perhaps with a solid-state hard drive, and new features for the iPhone. headline: Today in Business
summary: A BID TO EASE CREDIT IN EUROPE The European Central Bank said that it would extend a lending deadline in December to help the banking system through a period of unusually tight credit at the end of the year. The action represents a renewed effort by the bank to calm a lending system that had showed signs of returning to normal recently but now appears nearly as nervous as during the summer days when the global credit turmoil began. The bank's normal midmonth lending, which typically has a maturity of a single week, will be extended in December so that loans are not due until Jan. 4. ''In this operation, the E.C.B. will aim to satisfy the banking sector's liquidity needs for the entire two-week period,'' the bank said in a statement.

headline: Google Is Testing Video Ads

Yet on its most important pages, the results from its Web search engine, it limits ads to nothing more garish than a dozen words of text.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths PEDERSEN, LUCY K. S.
summary: PEDERSEN--Lucy K. S., a long-time resident of Rye, New York and Ocean Reef, Key Largo, Florida, died Monday, November 5, 2007 at her home in Rye. Lucy was born December 14, 1928 at New York Hospital to the late Rudolph Jay and Lucia Moran Schaefer Jr. Lucy attended Sacred Heart Convent in Maplehurst, NY, Convent of the Sacred Heart in Noroton, CT, and was a graduate of The Barmore School, in the Bronx, NY. An avid outdoors person, and all-around athlete, Lucy devoted much of her adult life to working within the Rye community including for many years joyfully and tireless caring for the disabled and the handicapped. She was President of The Rye Association for the Handicapped from 1986 to her retirement in 2006, when she was named President Emeritus of the organization. For her service and efforts she was awarded The City of Rye Commission on Human Rights Award in 1994, and The Rye YMCA Community Service Recognition Award in 2005. Lucy was loving mother to her four children, Peer Terrill (Jr.), Donna Fenech, Lyn Elizabeth, and Lucy Hazard; and a loving grandmother to her eight grandchildren Peer III, Paige, Madeline, Samantha, and Margaret Pedersen, and Nathan, Lorraine, and Kerri Fenech. She is also survived by her late father's wife, Janet Schaefer, by her siblings Edmee Schaefer Combs, Rudolph J. Schaefer, and Gwen T. Schaefer, and their large and loving families; and by her son-in-laws Craig Fenech and Scott Hazard, former daughter-in-law Mary Quick Pedersen, and former husband Peer T. Pedersen. The family will receive friends at the Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Road, Rye, NY on Wednesday, 2-4pm and 7-9pm. A mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at Resurrection Church on Thursday at 11am. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in memory of Lucy to The Rye Association For The Handicapped, Inc., P.O. Box 16, Rye, NY 10580-0016.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths GITTIS, HOWARD
summary: GITTIS--Howard. The partners, counsel, associates and staff of the firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison LLP express profound sorrow at the death of Howard Gittis, Vice Chairman of MacAndrews & Forbes Holdings Inc. Howard was our client and beloved friend. His joyful personality and sincere interest in all of those who worked with him will be greatly missed. We express our deepest sympathy to all members of his family. GITTIS--Howard. From the Schaffel family to all of the Gittis children and grandchildren. We couldn't have a better second family if we tried. Hope to spend the rest of the summers with you. Sorry for the great loss. Love Bill, Nancy and Alex GITTIS--Howard. The Board of Directors and management of Jones Apparel Group, Inc. express our deepest regrets at the passing of Howard Gittis, our Presiding Director and a member of our Board of Directors for 15 years. Howard's contributions to our Company were immensely valued, and his advice and guidance will be very much missed by those of us who had the privilege to work with him. We offer our heartfelt condolences to his family and associates. Wesley R. Card, President and Chief Executive Officer Jones Apparel Group, Inc. GITTIS--Howard. The family and friends of Howard Gittis mourn his passing on September 17th in New York City. Born in 1934 in Philadelphia, Howard Gittis is a graduate of the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania and Penn's Law School. He spent 25 years at Wolf, Block, Schorr and Solis-Cohen where he had served as the Chairman of the Executive Committee. Howard joined MacAndrews & Forbes in 1985, where he was Vice Chairman and Chief Administrative Officer until his death on September 17th. He was a loving father to Caroline Werther, Hope Sheft, Marjorie Katz and Emily Lambert Gittis, loving brother to Lenore Gittis, and loving grandfather to Samuel, Maxwell, Miles, Elijah, Sophie, Joshua and Henry. He is also survived by Sondra Gittis and Lynette King Gittis. Contributions in his honor can be made to the Howard Gittis Endowed Scholarship For Achievement and Excellence at Central High School, Philadelphia, The University of Pennsylvania, and Temple University. GITTIS--Howard. Dear Howard, summer camp is over and it's time to hang up our tennis rackets, store the golf clubs and put away the swim suits. I have loved every summer for 20 years, unfortunately for us camp will never open again. I will miss you and the great times we had. Your doubles tennis partner, Bill Schaffel

headline: Theme Songs and Others
summary: Presidential politics are plenty contentious, but they are nothing compared to band breakups. Mike Huckabee found himself caught in the middle of one this week. In October, Mr. Huckabee and his band, the Capitol Offense, joined a former member of the band Boston, Barry Goudreau, at the Surf Ballroom in Clear Lake, Iowa, for a gig.

headline: The Changing Commute
summary: Rosalyn Johnson, a registered nurse from Westbury, is so convinced high gasoline prices are here to stay that she recently opted to take a job in Manhattan over one in Central Islip, closer to home. ''It was more economical to take the job in the city,'' she said, while waiting for an eastbound Long Island Rail Road train at Pennsylvania Station. ''It would cost me more to drive to Central Islip than to buy a $211 monthly train pass.''

headline: The Changing Commute: Demand for Rides Soars
summary: Two months ago, Michele Martin ditched her 10-mile commute from Stamford to Greenwich in favor of riding Metro-North. Gasoline prices were the main reason, she said, but not the only one. ''I would see a billboard once in a while saying, 'Do one thing.' That cinched it for me,'' she said. Now, she doubts that she would ever go back to driving.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths BULGER, MR. ARTHUR C.
summary: BULGER--Mr. Arthur C., age 81, of Woodbridge, beloved husband of 53 years to Isabelle T. Bulger passed away on Saturday, December 15, 2007. Arthur was born on March 7, 1926 in Brooklyn, New York. He was a graduate of LaSalle Military Academy and Yale University. Mr. Bulger served during WWII with both the U.S. Army and the U.S. Navy. After graduating from Yale in 1947 with degrees in engineering and accounting, he joined The U.S. Rubber Company in Naugatuck as an industrial engineer. In 1952, he co-founded the Consulting Firm, Bavier, Bulger & Goodyear. The firm operated internationally for over 50 years and was a leader in developing innovative manufacturing methods for Fortune 1000 clients. He was a member of the Board of Directors for Lava Crucible, Saxonburg Ceramics, American Paper Products and Elliptipar, Inc. A life long sailor, Arthur and his wife began sailing together on the schooner Truelove. He cruised and raced extensively, owning a series of boats named Starlight and was a longtime member of The Milford Yacht Club and the Off Sounding Club. In addition to his wife, he leaves three children, Ellen Bulger, A. Christopher Bulger and Jean Pugh, along with six grandchildren, Emmet, Max, Zoe, Kate, Christopher and Alex. He also leaves two sisters, Barbara O'Reilly and Kay Lynch. Friends may call today from 4 to 7pm in the Cody-White Funeral Home, in Milford, CT. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held on Wednesday at 11am in Our Lady of the Assumption Church, Center Road, Woodbridge, CT. Commital will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his memory to the CT Food Bank in New Haven. www.cody whitefuneralservice.com

Livezey, Professor of Urban and Religious Studies and Director of the Ecologies of Learning Project at the Seminary. Lowell helped us all understand the life and work of the churches and especially the intellectual task of preparation for ministry more clearly. Dr. Craig Dykstra, Senior Vice President, Religion of Lilly Endowment Inc., stated that ''Lowell Livezey's work on religion and urban culture is path-breaking -a permanent contribution. His patient, generous and imaginative work with pastors and other religious leaders in Chicago, Boston and New York, as well as with scholars, will bear great fruit for many years to come.'' Dr. Livezey is survived by his wife, Dr. Lois Gehr Livezey, Director of the Globalization Project of the Center for World Christianity at NYTS. Contributions in Dr. Livezey's memory may be made to the Lowell W. Livezey Fund, Ecologies of Learning, New York Theological Seminary, 475 Riverside Drive, Suite 500, New York, NY 10115. headline: Paid Notice: Deaths Pedersen, Lucy K.
summary: PEDERSEN--Lucy K. S., a long-time resident of Rye, New York and Ocean Reef, Key Largo, Florida, died Monday, November 5, 2007 at her home in Rye. Lucy was born December 14, 1928 at New York Hospital to the late Rudolph Jay and Lucia Moran Schaefer Jr. Lucy attended Sacred Heart Convent in Maplehurst, NY, Convent of the Sacred Heart in Noroton, CT, and was a graduate of The Barmore School, in the Bronx, NY. An avid outdoors person, and all-around athlete, Lucy devoted much of her adult life to working within the Rye community including for many years joyfully and tireless caring for the disabled and the handicapped. She was President of The Rye Association for the Handicapped from 1986 to her retirement in 2006, when she was named President Emeritus of the organization. For her service and efforts she was awarded The City of Rye Commission on Human Rights Award in 1994, and The Rye YMCA Community Service Recognition Award in 2005. Lucy was loving mother to her four children, Peer Terrill (Jr.), Donna Fenech, Lyn Elizabeth, and Lucy Hazard; and a loving grandmother to her eight grandchildren Peer III, Paige, Madeline, Samantha, and Margaret Pedersen, and Nathan, Lorraine, and Kerri Fenech. She is also survived by her late father's wife, Janet Schaefer, by her siblings Edmee Schaefer Combs, Rudolph J. Schaefer, and Gwen T. Schaefer, and their large and loving families; and by her son-in-laws Craig Fenech and Scott Hazard, former daughter-in-law Mary Quick Pedersen, and former husband Peer T. Pedersen. The family will receive friends at the Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Road, Rye, NY on Wednesday, 2-4pm and 7-9pm. A mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at Resurrection Church on Thursday at 11am. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in memory of Lucy to The Rye Association For The Handicapped, Inc., P.O. Box 16, Rye, NY 10580-0016.

headline: Designers Teach Glass (and Themselves) New Tricks
summary: Correction Appended Summer hadn't quite arrived in the city over the Memorial Day weekend, but in the garden of the Cooper-Hewitt, National Design Museum, on upper Fifth Avenue, it was several hundred degrees in the shade. Onstage in the Corning Museum GlassLab, four sweat-beaded men in black T-shirts rotated elongated rods -- tipped with molten glass hot enough to ignite anything it touched, whether metal, wood or flesh -- with the nonchalance of baton twirlers.

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
summary: AT&T AND VERIZON WIN EXEMPTIONS AT&T and Verizon Communications can each merge their local and long-distance telephone operations with fewer government restrictions than some rivals wanted, the Federal Communications Commission said yesterday. In a order posted on its Web site, the F.C.C. exempted the two companies from price caps and other so-called dominant-carrier rules on long-distance service.

headline: Apple's Latest Opens a Developers' Playground
summary: When Apple opens its online App Store for iPhone software on Thursday, Steven P. Jobs will be making an attempt to dominate the next generation of computing as it moves toward Internet-connected mobile devices. The store, which will offer more than 500 software applications, including games, educational programs, mobile commerce and business productivity tools, may be a far more important development than the iPhone 3G, which goes on sale at the same time. An abundance of software could make the iPhone's operating system dominant among an abundance of competing phones.

headline: Dealbook Extra
summary: Frank's Friends at Google Look who Google's turned to for help.

headline: The 7th Annual Year in Ideas
summary: LEFT-HAND-TURN ELIMINATION [28] It seems that sitting in the left lane, engine idling, waiting for oncoming traffic to clear so you can make a left-hand turn, is minutely wasteful -- of time and peace of mind, for sure, but also of gas and therefore money. Not a ton of gas and money if we're talking about just you and your Windstar, say, but immensely wasteful if we're talking about more than 95,000 big square brown trucks delivering packages every day. And this realization -- that when you operate a gigantic fleet of vehicles, tiny improvements in the efficiency of each one will translate to huge savings overall -- is what led U.P.S. to limit further the number of left-hand turns its drivers make. The company employs what it calls a ''package flow'' software program, which among other hyperefficient practices involving the packing and sorting of its cargo, maps out routes for every one of its drivers, drastically reducing the number of left-hand turns they make (taking into consideration, of course, those instances where not to make the left-hand turn would result in a ridiculously circuitous route).

summary: A Cone of Swirl For Yahoo The flavor of the day on Tuesday at Yahoo, when it announced second-quarter results, was ''external swirl.''

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths Tolling, Sven
summary: TOLLING--Dr. Sven T., 63, passed on December 15th, 2007, in Sweden. His career in Veterinary medicine spanned 36 years, working on pivotal issues concerning animal health, including many years at Pfizer Inc., New York, and as the chairman of the Swedish Equestrian Federation. He was awarded Doctor h.c. at the University of Agricultural Sciences, Uppsala, Sweden in 1999. He touched the lives of many and is remembered as a generous, compassionate, vibrant, and gifted man. Always a passionate advocate of what is righteous and ethical, he will be remembered as a strong leader with a devotion to making a difference. He will be forever in the hearts and memories of his family: his wife, Dr. Kerstin Thoren-Tolling, his son Nils G. Tolling, his daughter-in-law Mina Konishi, and his brother Hans Tolling, with his family as well as many friends and colleagues. Services will be held in Sweden on January 8th. A Memorial Service will be held in Westport, Connecticut, in February. For information, please email: nils@tolling.org

headline: The Reports That Drew Federal Eyes To Spitzer
summary: Last summer, employees at a large New York bank detected something suspicious: Gov. Eliot Spitzer was moving around thousands of dollars in what they thought was an effort to conceal the fact that the money was his own, federal officials said on Tuesday. They said the apparent sleight of hand kept the transactions small and removed his name from deposits. The governor's actions prompted the bank to file alerts known as Suspicious Activity Reports with the Treasury Department, which were reviewed by I.R.S. agents on Long Island, the federal officials said.

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
summary: MARKETS LIMP INTO HOLIDAY A late sell-off sent stock markets down sharply, with the Dow Jones industrial average closing at its lowest level since April. Widespread worries about expensive oil, a sagging dollar and a gloomy outlook for economic growth took a toll on investors.

headline: DEALBOOK EXTRA
summary: Bronfman's Sour Note Warner Music Group struck a sour note with investors on Thursday: The private equity backed company reported a wider loss for the second quarter -- $37 million compared with $27 million during the same period of 2007 -- and suspended its dividend in what it described as an effort to maintain ''financial flexibility.''

headline: Apply to Birthday Suit
summary: APPARENTLY, AMERICANS can't get enough of the British all-natural beauty line Nude, created by Bryan Meehan (a founder of the British organic food stores Fresh & Wild, which Whole Foods bought for $38 million in 2004). In June, Nude flew off English beauty counters; the collection arrived at Barneys New York last month ($14 to $100) to an equally enthusiastic response. America's darlings? Cubes of lip balm ($14) and the subtly fragrant Hibiscus Monoi body oil ($68). Nude's green genes are evident in its pure ingredients, biodegradable packaging and celebrity pedigree. Bono and Ali Hewson are investors (the name Nude is the inverse of Edun, their organic clothing line); the model Christy Turlington was an early product-tester.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths Wheeler, Wilmot Fitch
summary: WHEELER--Wilmot Fitch, Jr., a manufacturing company executive and an international financial administrator died Friday, September 28, 2007 in Southport, Connecticut from complications due to Alzheimer's Disease; he was 84 years old. Wilmot F. Wheeler Jr. graduated from St. Paul's School, Concord, NH. A veteran of World War II, he was decorated with a Bronze Star, then graduated from Yale University in 1945, and did his post-graduate work at New York University. He received an honorary LLD from Sacred Heart University, Fairfield, CT. During his life Mr. Wheeler was President, Chairman and Executive Officer of American Chain and Cable, Co., Inc. Bridgeport, CT, and Chairman of Jelliff Corporation, Southport, CT. He was also CEO of Dollar Dry Dock Savings Bank, NYC, CEO of Manhattan National Corporation, Vice President of the William T. Morris Foundation, Inc. and President of the Wilmot Wheeler Foundation, Inc. Mr. Wheeler was a member of many Boards of Directors including People's Bank, Bridgeport, CT.; Pratt Read Corp; Pujol y Tarrago SAA/Spain; Union Central Life Insurance Company; Dominion Chair Co, Ltd.; American District Telegraph Company; British Wire Products Ltd, England; Cables Automotrices SA, Mexico; FATA Spa, Italy; Arthur G. McKee and Company; American Farm School, Greece; Bridgeport Hospital, Bridgeport, CT; and University of Bridgeport. Mr. Wheeler was a member of Pequot Yacht Club, Southport, CT, and the Country Club of Fairfield, Fairfield, CT, where he served as President. Wilmot is survived by his wife, Nonnye Landers Wheeler, and children, Wilmot III, James, Susan, Tracy, and Alexa, twelve grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. He is predeceased by his first wife, Barbara Rutherfurd Wheeler and son John.

headline: SHOPPING WITH SIMON DOONAN: House Gifts For Quirky Friends
summary: SIMON DOONAN, the creative director of Barneys New York, was dressed in a style reflecting the ideas in his newest book, ''Eccentric Glamour: Creating an Insanely More Fabulous You.'' In it, he creates three personality types: the flighty, exotic gypsy; the super-confident socialite; and the on-the-edge existentialist, and suggests that anyone who is tired of the ordinary should make the leap to eccentric glamour by cultivating one of those styles.

headline: The Leaning Landmark of Broadway
summary: Talk about endangered landmarks. The elegant cast-iron building at 287 Broadway, which ''graphically illustrates the transformation of lower Broadway in the 19th century from a residential boulevard into the city's commercial center'' (as the Landmarks Preservation Commission put it), is leaning about eight inches to the south.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths LIVEZEY, LOWELL W
summary: LIVEZEY--Lowell W. New York Theological Seminary announces with great sadness the passing on December 9, 2007, of Dr. Lowell W. Livezey, Professor of Urban and Religious Studies and Director of the Ecologies of Learning Project at the Seminary. Dr. Livezey directed large studies of urban congregations, using ethnographic data assembled in collaboration with colleagues and students in Chicago, Boston, and New York. He argued that the ''religion factor'' is more salient than often recognized in the economic, demographic, and spatial restructuring of modern industrial cities. Dr. Livezey received the B.A. from Swarthmore College and the M. Th. and D. Min. degrees from the University of Chicago School of Divinity. He spent two decades in the peace movement before beginning his second career in studying communities, meanings, culture, and social change. In 2005, Dr. Livezey became the founding Director of the Ecologies of Learning Project (EOL) at NYTS, funded through a major grant from Lilly Endowment Inc. Lowell Livezey was a person of immense insight, wisdom and compassion, of great integrity and depth, and an outstanding colleague. He embodied the values of teaching, learning and research that lie at the heart of the scholarly endeavor. He also was a friend, a caring human being, someone around whom community was easily formed. In the language that is familiar to the people of faith, Lowell simply was a blessing to NYTS. Lowell helped us all understand the life and work of the churches and especially the intellectual task of preparation for ministry more clearly. Dr. Craig Dykstra, Senior Vice President, Religion of Lilly Endowment Inc., stated that ''Lowell Livezey's work on religion and urban culture is path-breaking -a permanent contribution. His patient, generous and imaginative work with pastors and other religious leaders in Chicago, Boston and New York, as well as with scholars, will bear great fruit for many years to come.'' Dr. Livezey is survived by his wife, Dr. Lois Gehr Livezey, Director of the Globalization Project of the Center for World Christianity at NYTS. Contributions in Dr. Livezey's memory may be made to the Lowell W. Livezey Fund, Ecologies of Learning, New York Theological Seminary, 475 Riverside Drive, Suite 500, New York, NY 10115. A memorial will be held on January 26, 2008, 10:00 am, at The Riverside Church, 490 Riverside Drive, New York City. Dr. Dale T. Irvin, President Dr. Diane T. Ashley, Chair of the Board of Trustees

headline: Steel Worker Is Hurt in Fall From Building
summary: Just one day after thousands of workers gathered to mourn the loss of the 13 people killed in construction accidents in New York City this year, a steel worker was critically injured on Tuesday when he fell 25 feet from a building under construction on East 29th Street in Manhattan. The authorities said the worker, Christopher Gunn, 28, was trying to maneuver a 20-foot steel I-beam being hoisted into place by a crane about 8:30 a.m. when he slipped and fell from the second story of the building, which is under construction between First Avenue and Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive.

(Maureen); cherished grandfather of Martha, Sara, Jake, Peter, Meaghan, Joseph, Mary Kate, Bobby and Erin. headline: Paid Notice: Deaths TSAI, GERALD
summary: TSAI--Gerald , loving friend of 57 years, consummate gentleman, brilliant businessman. You will be greatly missed. My deepest sympathies to your children and grandchildren. Robert Weltz, 415 Hot Springs Road., Montecito, CA TSAI--Gerald, Jr., 79, resident of Manhattan and Rye, NY, died peacefully July 9, 2008. Beloved father of Christopher and Veronica. Caring grandfather of Vanessa O'Brien. Jerry was an enormously talented and successful businessman, serving as a Chairman, President and Chief Executive officer of several large publicly traded companies. He was known as a highly gifted analytical problem solver and a skilled negotiator. His understanding of the capital markets was unparalleled, recognizing opportunities where others saw confusion. Jerry was born in Shanghai, China, on March 10, 1929, and attended St. John's Middle School and St. John's University. He came to the United States in 1947 and, after one semester at Wesleyan University, transferred to Boston University, where he earned both a Bachelor of Arts in Economics from the College of Liberal Arts and a Master of Arts in Economics from the Graduate School of Arts and Sciences in 1949. In addition, Jerry attended courses at the School of Management. Jerry began his distinguished investment career in 1951 as a security analyst at Bache & Company. A year later, he joined the Boston firm of Fidelity Management and Research Company, Inc., as a security analyst. After only six years, at the age of 29, he started the Fidelity Capital Fund, Fidelity's first public growth fund. He has been credited as one of the main initiators of the modern performance fund idea. At Fidelity he rapidly rose through the corporate ranks, ascending to Assistant Vice President of Fidelity Fund, Inc., to Vice President, to director and Executive Vice President of the company in 1963. In 1965, Jerry established the Tsai Management & Research Corporation and Manhattan Fund, which proved to be a huge success. The initial offering was planned for $25 million but the public's response was so enthusiastic that the fund was greatly oversubscribed and $247 million in shares were sold. He joined CNA Financial Corp in 1967 as President and served until 1973. Jerry was also Chairman of Associated Madison Companies, lnc., the cornerstone of Primerica's financial services business, He joined Primerica Corporation, then American Can Company, as Executive Vice President of financial services and as a member of the company's Board of Directors in 1982, when the company acquired Associated Madison in its first move into the financial services industry. He rose to Chief Executive Officer and Chairman, becoming the first ChineseAmerican to lead a company in the Dow Jones Industrials Index. He became the principal strategist in building Primerica's financial services businesses, which included the purchase of Smith Barney in 1987. Jerry was a devoted son, and regularly sought out his mother's advice before making a major business decision. For instance, Ruth encouraged him to join Primerica, despite his reservations, and then backed his idea of acquiring Smith Barney. He often said that her faith in him have gave him the confidence to succeed. From 1993 to 1997, he served as Chairman, President, and Chief Executive Officer of Delta Life Corporation, a life insurance; and annuity company. Jerry also served on the boards of several companies, including United Rentals, lnc., Sequa Corp., Zenith National Insurance Corp., Triarc Companies, Inc. Apollo Investment Corp., and Saks Inc. In addition to his business successes Jerry was a highly distinguished member of the community serving on a variety of philanthropic boards including the Boston University Board of Trustees and the Norton Museum of Art Board of Trustees. He also served as a trustee of the New York University Medical Center and School of Medicine Foundation Board. He was a member of the Board of Overseers of the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania. Jerry has been honored for his philanthropic and humanitarian work, receiving a Doctor of Humane Letters from Boston University in 2003. He received the Man of the Year Award from the Chinatown Planning Council of New York and the Boston University Alumni Award for Distinguished Public Service to the Profession in 1985. Jerry was an Associate Founder of Boston University, and served on the Board of Trustees for many years. He was a trustee emeritus at the time of his death. Funeral services will be held Saturday, July 12, 5pm, at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel 1076 Madison Ave., New York, NY. TSAI--Jerry. Jerry was a major influence in my life. In 1967, I asked him what firm I could go to so that I would be paid an equal salary to what men were being paid. He first said don't be ridiculous, and then advised me to buy a seat on the New York Stock Exchange and work for myself. On December 28, 2007, he joined me on the podium as I rang the ''Closing Bell'' at the NYSE in celebration of my 40th anniversary. Jerry gave me this brilliant idea, and I have always given him the credit for being the Inspiration behind my success. I will miss Jerry -he was a unique and very special person. Muriel ''Mickie'' Siebert TSAI--Gerald. To a very very special friend and a wonderful man who did more for his friends than himself. Gerald Tsai will be greatly missed. Fondly, Elaine Sargent TSAI--Gerald Jr. Dear Jerry, we miss our Sunday night diners and will think of you then, especially hearing of your deep respect, love and admiration for your mother. Marilyn and Bob TSAI--Gerald, Jr., 79. The Board of Directors of Apollo Investment Corporation offers its deepest and heartfelt condolences to the family of Gerald Tsai, Jr. on his recent passing. He was a beloved friend and a valuable member of our Board since its inception. He will be greatly missed. John Hannan, Chairman TSAI--Gerald Jr. The family of the late Norman E. Alexander remembers the long friendship between two extraordinary men. We extend our deepest sympathy to his family. The Family of the late Norman E. Alexander

headline: Comments of the Week
summary: The diversity situation in Nascar compared to other forms of motorsports sums up nicely why Nascar is a circus sideshow and not the real thing. Bernie Ecclestone didn't run an incentive program to get McLaren to hire Lewis Hamilton. The circumstances that produced the Danica Patrick phenomenon weren't manufactured (at least at first). Even the National Hot Rod Association, which gives Nascar a run for its money in terms of the least common denominator, found some driver diversity naturally.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
summary: T: DESIGN An article on March 16 in T: Design magazine, about glassLAB, a glass-design workshop that was part of the Design Miami fair in December, misstated the role that the architect Paul Haigh played in its formation. Haigh developed the program concept for glassLAB and designed its installation in Miami; he did not design its mobile glassblowing equipment (the Corning Museum of Glass did). The article also referred incorrectly to Liquid Fusion, Haigh's workshop at Domaine de Boisbuchet, a design retreat in France. The workshop existed before glassLAB; glassLAB did not lead to its creation. The article also referred incorrectly at one point to the museum as ''the company.'' Corning Inc., the glass company, is a separate entity.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths Hotarek, Rudolph T.
summary: HOTAREK--Rudolph T., of Port Washington, age 91 on June 7, 2008 after a prolonged illness. Beloved husband of the late Regina Jamison for 60 years. Devoted father of Gail Dwyer (Edward), Brian (Christine), Regina, Robert (Joan), and Christine Shepherd (Scott). Loving grandfather of 11 and proud greatgrandfather of six. Highly decorated veteran of WWII, having received two Purple Hearts for wounds sustained in combat, and the Bronze Star for valor. One of the few decorated war veterans of both the European and Asian campaigns. For 30 years he has run his own incentive marketing firm where he worked until retirement, at age 80. Co-founder and former president of Port Youth Activities. He was an instrumental force in St. Ignatius Retreat Program for over 20 years and was also an active member of St. Peter of Alcantara Church since 1953. He served many years on the Board of Governors at Plandome Country Club, where he enjoyed many hours on the golf course and cultivated many of his closest friendships. Reposing at Austin F. Knowles, Inc. Funeral Home Monday 2-4pm and 7-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday 9:30am, St. Peter of Alcantara R.C. Church. Interment Nassau Knolls Cemetery. Donations to St. Francis Hospital, 100 Port Washington Blvd., Roslyn, NY 11576 or Good Shepherd Hospice, 528 Mineola Ave, Carle Place, NY 11514 would be greatly appreciated.

headline: BITS
summary: Fire Sale at Offspring of Napster Shawn Fanning, above, has been close to the ideas that have changed the music business, but he never got them exactly right -- in large part because he was too early.

headline: BITS
summary: The Bugs in Virgin's Cabin There are a few kinks to work out of the vaunted in-flight entertainment system of Virgin America, the low-cost domestic airline that was introduced to great acclaim last month.

headline: BITS
summary: The Passion of Steve Jobs In an interview at the Macworld Expo last week, Steven P. Jobs, Apple's chief executive, was blunt when asked about the Kindle electronic book reader, above, from Amazon.com, which many have called the most promising device of its kind. Mr. Jobs said it would go nowhere, largely because Americans have stopped reading.

headline: The Next Debate
summary: The fate of the North Carolina debate is now in Senator Barack Obama's hands. CBS has formally offered the two Democratic candidates for president a 90-minute debate on April 27. Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's campaign announced Thursday that it would accept the invitation. But the Obama campaign, citing its preference for a debate before the primary in Pennsylvania on April 22, is still withholding a decision.

headline: A Giant Bookstore Goes Dark in Chelsea
summary: Wei Wei, visiting New York from the Michael Schultz Gallery in Beijing, showed up on Tuesday morning at the blocklong Barnes & Noble on the Avenue of the Americas, between 21st and 22nd Streets, in the old Ladies' Mile shopping district. He was looking for monographs of Sam Francis, Keith Haring, James Rosenquist and Frank Stella, whose work the gallery plans to exhibit. His hotel had recommended this particular Barnes & Noble for the strength of its art section.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths RAISS, ROBIN
summary: RAISS--Robin . The Directors, Officers and Employees of Tanenbaum-Harber Co., Inc. regretfully acknowledge the passing of our esteemed officer and friend, Robin Raiss after a long, valiant battle with breast cancer. Robin was a devoted Officer of our firm who served as a Vice President for over 14 years. She will be sorely missed by all those within the T&H family as well as by clients and insurance industry personnel who knew her. Memorial services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel at 180 West 76th St. on Friday, August 15th at 11:15am. Walter L. Harris, CEO and President

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths JESSELSON, ERICA
summary: JESSELSON--Erica. The SAR Academy and High School Family mourns the passing of our beloved matriarch Erica Jesselson, founder and visionary who nurtured the success of generations of graduates both spiritually and financially throughout the school's 39 year history. Together with her husband, Ludwig, of blessed memory, the Jesselson's redefined Jewish philanthropy, bringing unprecedented generosity to countless institutions. Through her charitable work, and the work of her children, Michael, Danny, and Bunny, the Jesselson name today is synonymous with acts of loving kindness and dedication to the faith of our people throughout the world. Our sincere condolences to her loving sons and daughters-inlaw, Daniel and Yael, Michael and Linda, Benjamin and Phyllis; to her loving sister, Lucy Lang, her grandchildren, great-grandchildren and the entire family. May the merit of her deeds bring comfort to her family and all of Israel. Jack C. Bendheim, President JESSELSON--Erica. The Aleph Society mourns the passing of Erica Jesselson, matriarch of the Jesselson family. The legacy of her loving kindness continues through the good deeds and the grace of her children, grandchildren and greatgrandchildren. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Adin Steinsaltz JESSELSON--Erica. The Board of Directors of American Eagle Outfitters, Inc expresses condolences on the passing of Erica Jesselson, beloved mother of AEO Board member, Michael Jesselson, and the wife of the late Ludwig Jesselson, of blessed memory. Erica touched the lives of many through her involvement in community service and her support of Jewish education, arts and culture. We join the many in expressing heartfelt sympathy to the entire Jesselson family, Michael (Linda), Daniel (Yael), Benjamin (Phyllis), sister, Mrs. Lucy Long, grandchildren and Great-grandchildren. Jay Schottenstein, Chairman of the Board James O'Donnell, Chief Executive Officer JESSELSON--Erica. With her passionate commitment to preserving the artifacts of our culture and her profound appreciation for the books and documents that record our history and the traditions of our people, Erica Jesselson helped steer the course of Yeshiva University's libraries. Our friend and champion is gone. We pray that her family will be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Yehi zichrah baruch. Pearl Berger, Benjamin Gottesman Librarian/ Dean of Libraries The Librarians and Library Staff at Yeshiva University JESSELSON--Erica. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) mourn the loss of Erica Jesselson of Riverdale, NY. A woman of boundless energy and exuberance who was involved with numerous causes in the Jewish community, Mrs. Jesselson was a devoted supporter of our organization for more than a quarter century. She was a Technion Guardian, representing the highest level of support, a Life Trustee of the ATS Board of Regents and a past member of the national Board of Directors. With a passion for the spiritual wellbeing of Technion students, faculty and staff, Mrs. Jesselson, together with her husband Ludwig, of blessed memory, established the Ohel Aharon Synagogue on the Technion campus and supported projects that helped the synagogue and Jewish life flourish, including the Cultural Programs Fund. The Jesselsons also established the Talmudic Study Center, making it possible for Technion students who so desired to lead an observant lifestyle, while at the same time be fully involved in a world-class science and engineering institution. To her sons Michael, Daniel and Benjamin Jesselson, and the entire Jesselson family, we offer our heartfelt condolences. American Technion Society Joan Seidel, President Dr. Stephen A. Laser, Chairman, Board of Directors Melvyn H. Bloom, Executive Vice President Alan Forman, New York Metropolitan Region Chairman Nancy Gad-Harf, New York Metropolitan Region Director JESSELSON--Erica. An exceptional woman whose goodness, insight and creativity knew no bounds. Former MDS parent, grandparent and Past President of our PTA. Erica, together with her husband Ludwig were early promoters and generous supporters of Manhattan Day School in particular and yeshiva education in general. Sincere condolences to her children, Daniel (Yael), Michael (Linda) and Benjamin (Phyllis), grandchildren, great-grandchildren and devoted sister Lucy Lang. Manhattan Day School Mr. Elliot Gibber, Chairman of the Board Deveaux Baron, Eric Goldstein Co-Presidents Rabbi Mordechai Besser, Principal Robert Insel, Executive Director JESSELSON--Erica. The Board and staff of the YIVO Institute for Jewish Research mourn the passing of our dear friend and devoted former trustee. She was a strong advocate and supporter of YIVO, one who understood the importance of our work in Eastern European Jewish Studies. An avid reader, she took great pride in YIVO's many recent scholarly publications. Her unique energy and commitment will be sorely missed. Our deepest sympathy goes to her children and grandchildren. She was an example to us all. May her memory be a blessing. Bruce Slovin, Chairman Dr. Carl J. Rheins, Exec. Director JESSELSON--Erica. American Friends of The Hebrew University (AFHU) and The Hebrew University of Jerusalem (HU) are deeply saddened by the passing of Erica Jesselson. Her life was one of extraordinary dedication to Clal Yisrael. She and her husband, Ludwig, recipients of honorary doctorates from HU, established the Ludwig Jesselson Chair in Library Sciences and were benefactors of the Jewish National and University Library. They contributed to medicine, Jewish studies, nanoscience and student scholarships. We offer our heartfelt condolences to her sister, Lucy Lang, her sons and their wives: Michael and Linda; Daniel and Yael; and Benjamin and Phyllis, as well as the entire family. May Erica Jesselson's legacy live on as an inspiration to others. HU Prof. Menachem Magidor President AFHU Ira Lee Sorkin Chairman George A. Schieren President Peter T. Willner National Executive Director JESSELSON--Erica. Jay and Jeanie Schottenstein and family extend their deepest condolences to their friends Michael, Linda, Samuel, Roni, Jonathan, and Maya on the passing of their beloved mother, mother-in-law and grandmother, Erica Jesselson. Erica was a great lady, a woman of tremendous energy, creativity and kindness. Her spirited involvement in Jewish communal activities combined with her leadership in Jewish education, love of Israel and passion for the arts have left an indelible mark on the quality of our lives. We extend condolences to the entire Jesselson family on their loss. May the survivors be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jay and Jeanie Schottenstein Joseph and Lindsay Schottenstein Jonathan Schottenstein Jeffrey Schottenstein JESSELSON--Erica. We mourn the loss of a treasured jewel of the Jewish people. A singular and dynamic woman of intense energy, vision and creativity, her very being radiated strength, compassion and generosity. Erica lived each day rooted with a firm belief that her resources were granted by the Almighty to benefit others. She taught members of her family, her huge circle of friends and countless others that the meaning of life was not acquiring but giving. When one considers the range and scope of the charitable activities to which she was devoted, and the personal involvement and caring that she exhibited as a lay leader, one understands the definition of a true philanthropic role model. When one realizes the joy, happiness, peace of mind and healing that she helped to provide, the religious and secular knowledge she helped to foster, and the wonderful aesthetic sense that she brought to so many organizations and institutions, one begins to understand the depth of her persona. Of course, most of these activities were accomplished side-by-side with her beloved ''Luddy''. The name Jesselson is synonymous with the founding, growth and development of Shaare Zedek Medical Center. Through her service as Chair of the American Committee and Chair of the National Women's Division, we were the beneficiaries of Erica's leadership, creativity and inspiration. The world-class facilities of the Jesselson Heart Center at Shaare Zedek stand as a beacon of hope to the more than 25,000 cardiac patients that are treated there each year. We will forever be grateful to her and will always cherish her memory. To Erica's sister Lucy Lang, sons Michael (current Chair of the American Committee), Daniel and Benjamin, their spouses, all the grandchildren and the entire family, we offer our heartfelt condolences. May they be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. American Committee for Shaare Zedek Medical Center in Jerusalem Jack C. Bendheim, President Menno Ratzker, Vice Chair Phil Friedman, Vice Pres Sidney G. Adler, Treasurer Emeritus Ronald Abrams, Treasurer Abby Ellison Kanarek, Secretary Prof. Jonathan Halevy, Dir. General Lee Weinbach, Pres. Nat'l Women's Div. Fayge Schwartz, VP, Nat'l Women's Div. Ann Dachs, VP, Nat'l Women's Div. Paul Glasser, Exec. Vice Pres JESSELSON--Erica. The Board of Directors, residents and staff of the Hebrew Home at Riverdale mourn the loss of our beloved friend, Erica Jesselson. We will miss her lifelong passion, dedication and commitment to Jewish education, Israel and Jewish culture. She was a true woman of valor. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her children and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion. The Hebrew Home at Riverdale Jeffrey S. Maurer, Chairman Burton P. Resnick, Chairman, Building Committee Daniel Reingold, President & CEO David Pomeranz, Associate Exec. Director

headline: ABC, CBS and NBC Will Join Forces for a Prime-Time Cancer Fund-Raiser
summary: ABC, CBS and NBC have agreed to set aside the same hour of prime-time television on the first Friday night in September for a live, joint telethon benefiting cancer research, representatives for the networks said in interviews. Among those who encouraged the networks to put aside their competitive instincts, albeit temporarily, was Katie Couric, anchor of the ''CBS Evening News,'' who will appear on the fund-raiser alongside her principal rivals, Brian Williams of NBC and Charles Gibson of ABC. All three have had immediate family members die of the disease, and another principal, Jeff Zucker, the president and chief executive of NBC and Ms. Couric's former boss, is a colon cancer survivor. To publicize the benefit, which is being called Stand Up to Cancer, Ms. Couric will return on Wednesday to NBC's ''Today,'' the program she left in 2006 after more than a decade. (Her former partner, Matt Lauer, teased her return on Tuesday's program, coyly saying she was coming back to make a major announcement.) On ''Today,'' Ms. Couric will be joined by Mr. Gibson and Mr. Williams, who are also expected to appear with her on Wednesday on ''Good Morning America'' on ABC and ''The Early Show'' on CBS.

headline: Above the City, a Juggling Act That Combines Patience, Precision and Danger
summary: They sit in cubicles in the sky, at the controls inside an operator's cab 20 or 30 stories above the streets of New York City. They spend their days hooking and hoisting -- even when off-duty, since a number of them unwind by going fishing. They have withstood sudden wind gusts, irate contractors and even lightning strikes, all in a day's work, for a maximum salary of about $60 an hour. They are the city's crane operators. Two deadly construction crane collapses in Manhattan in less than three months -- one that killed seven people on March 15 and another that killed two people on Friday -- have saddened and rattled crane operators, bringing their often unseen, unheralded and misunderstood jobs into the public eye.

headline: In Sync To Pierce The Cloud
summary: ''Cloud computing'' is a white-hot buzzword these days. It basically means working with files and programs that reside on the Internet, beyond your company's walls -- out there in the ''cloud.'' Everyday consumers are doing cloud computing, too, maybe without even realizing it. When you use an Internet-based backup service, or Google's online word processor or spreadsheet, or a Gmail or Yahoo mail account, you're working with data on a secure Internet server somewhere -- not on your hard drive.

headline: BITS
